body: RARE is the ad agency president who as the lid is placed on the coffin of 1982 can say, ''None of my clients cut their ad budgets this year.'' Well, Mario Trombone not only can but did. Yesterday, as a matter of fact. The agency is Tromson Monroe Advertising, which quite unintentionally began specializing in travel and leisure time advertising soon
title: Advertising; Good News In Travel Accounts

body: "At any political meeting, nine-tenths of the questions from the homeowners are about multifamily housing,'' says Hy Sardy, chairman of the Midwood Development Corporation in Brooklyn. When homeowners live in areas that have high concentrations of rental housing, preservation of the quality of the rental stock becomes a major concern. Accordingly,
title: HOMEOWNERS WORKING TO IMPROVE RENTAL PROPERTY

body: DRESSY The Metropolitan Museum of Art, at 81st Street and Fifth Avenue (736-2211), is a veritable department store (nonprofit, nonselling) of art, with sections that handle everything from the best on canvas and in stone to the oldest in home furnishings and the most diverse in musical instruments. Garments are one flight down from the main floor,
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: Three teen-agers were wounded, one critically, when a youth opened fire with a shotgun early yesterday during a dance in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the police said. The youths were attending a disco dance in the second-floor community room of a public housing project at 2960 West 24th Street, said Lieut. Thomas Dowling. The shooting,
title: THE CITY; 3 Hurt in Shooting At Coney I. Dance

body: When Fiorello H. La Guardia railed against ''them'' on the radio, we knew who they were. If Mayor La Guardia went up against a big guy, he did it directly. ''Well, lo and behold, you did not have long to wait, did you, Western Union?'' And, ''Now, remember, butchers, I think I warned you last week.'' On Sunday afternoon, my parents and I listened
title: 'LITTLE FLOWER' WAS A THORN IN BIGGIES' SIDES

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 24 food establishments last week for violating the health code. In addition, the department named six that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and five that were closed after failing to do so. VIOLATIONS Chicken Burger World, 404 Ave. of the Americas. Tavola Calda da Alfredo, 285
title: 24 Food Places Listed For Health Violations

body: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn yesterday reversed her subordinates and said her office would seek a rape indictment in a case that provoked a sharp dispute over the state's recently amended rape law. Her office had previously said that under the amended statute a rape charge was not possible in the case of a woman who said she was
title: DISPUTED RAPE CASE WILL PROCEED, MISS HOLTZMAN SAYS

body: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday that a recent change in the state's rape law - intended to make prosecution easier - had prevented the filing of a rape charge in the case of a woman who said she was forcibly raped twice but had not feared death or serious injury. But the District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, said last night
title: NEW LAW CITED IN DROPPING RAPE CHARGE

body: A police officer was accidentally shot in the left leg by his partner yesterday as the two chased four teen-agers suspected of stealing a car in Brooklyn, the police said. The wounded officer was identified as Timothy Barry of the 60th Precinct in the Coney Island section. He suffered a superficial leg wound when his partner, Joseph Revello,
title: Brooklyn Officer Slightly Hurt When Partner's Gun Goes Off

body: Claire Roth has unusual feet. They have very narrow heels and socalled flexible arches, so she found that she could not walk very far in boots without pain. Mrs. Roth, who is director of the Mercantile Library, decided two years ago to buy a pair of made-to-measure boots. She went to T.O. Dey at 509 Fifth Avenue, where she chose a color (taupe) and
title: FOR THE HARD-TO-FIT: CUSTOM BOOTS

body: Almost 4,000 jobs have been created or saved in New York City by an 18-month-old Consolidated Edison Company program that offers reduced electricity rates to commercial customers who agree to expand or relocate in depressed neighborhoods, according to the city and the utility. More than 1,000 businesses in the South Bronx and parts of Brooklyn have
title: CON ED RATES PROGRAM CLAIMS PROGRESS ON JOBS

body: The New York City Department of Health named 15 food establishments last week that had violated the city's health code. The department also listed 10 restaurants that had been allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and eight that had been closed for failure to do so. body: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was shot and critically wounded last night for no apparent reason as he stood with friends on a Coney Island street corner, the police said. The victim, Lenny Lamagna, of 2009 72d Street in the Bay Ridge section, was shot once in the head at 8:30 P.M. at the intersection of West 37th Street and Neptune Avenue, the
title: YOUTH IS WOUNDED IN CONEY I.

body: A self-employed distributor of handbags and umbrellas suffered a fatal heart attack Tuesday night as he was telling two police officers that he had been abducted from outside a Brooklyn bank and robbed of about $2,000 in cash, the police said yesterday. The victim, 47-year-old Nathan Esses of 1789 East Second Street in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst
title: THE CITY; Heart Attack Fatal To Robbery Victim

body: A gunman shooting from a 17-story apartment building in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn wounded a passing motorist yesterday, the police said. Then, as the police were searching for the gunman, a man in the same building, at 2946 West 43d Street, barricaded himself and his estranged wife in their sixth-floor apartment and held her hostage for
title: MOTORIST IN BROOKLYN IS SHOT BY A GUNMAN FIRING FROM BUILDING

body: D ixon Terry, a tall, red-haired, red-bearded dairy farmer from Greenfield, Iowa., spent a whirlwind 24 hours in New York yesterday. Up to then he had never been east of Chicago, never been on a plane and never seen the ocean. Mr. Terry, aged 33, also raises corn and soybeans. He was in New York as a board member of the United States Farmers
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; IOWA FARMER IN THE BIG CITY

body: Two gunmen entered a Brooklyn pharmacy yesterday and briefly held two employees prisoner before collapsing from prescription drugs they took off shelves and consumed, the police said. The gunmen, who were not immediately identified, were taken unconscious to Coney Island Hospital where their condition was critical, the police said. The gunmen
title: THE CITY; Pharmacy's Wares Subdue 2 Gunmen

body: AT the turn of the century, Sheepshead Bay was a favored resort of the rich. Most came for its race track, its fine seafood restaurants and the s alubrious sea breezes that blew in from the Atlantic. Lillian Russell, Diamond Jim Brady and Lillie Langtry were among t he famous folk who frequented Sheepshead Bay, and they were often s een strolling
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: SHEEPSHEAD BAY

body: Mario M. Cuomo brought his campaign for governor to two predominantly Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn yesterday, while Lewis E. Lehrman, his Republican opponent, also did some running - clocking a snappy 32 minutes and 20 seconds in the five-mile New York City Marathon computer run through Central Park. Mr. Lehrman, in a statement, criticized Mr.
title: LEHRMAN TAKES RACE TO PARK AS CUOMO GOES TO BROOKLYN

body: act plays are in rehearsal at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. A revival of ''After the Fall'' opens this weekend at the Jewish Repertory Theater. And in February, after ''A View From the Bridge'' has arrived in New York, he will journey to Peking to direct ''Death of a Salesman'' in Chinese - with a Chinese director, Yin Ro Chang, who is
title: From Broadway to Peking, it's Miller Time

body: Three adjacent rooming houses for psychiatric patients and the elderly in Sea Gate, the private community on the western tip of Coney Island, have been found by the state to be operating illegally. In response to complaints from residents and neighbors, the state inspected the houses Aug. 2 and found that many of the residents needed some sort of
title: 3 BROOKLYN ROOMING HOUSES MUST BE LICENSED, STATE SAYS

body: T he New York Aquarium in Coney Island is a wonderful place to look at marine life - but you should see the ones that got away. Take Dolphin. Dolphin was gamboling in the waters around the Brooklyn Navy Yard, too far north for a self-respecting warm-water dolphin. Aquarium people went out, took a look and judged it to be lost. But they watched it
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; To the Rescue

body: New York City officials hope to divert $88 million from the construction of a new sewage plant so they can repair two crumbling treatment plants in Brooklyn that now threaten to release raw sewage into surrounding waters. Last month the city said it was scaling down plans for the North River plant on Manhattan's Upper West Side, thereby saving $240
title: NEW YORK ACTS TO END THREAT OF SEWAGE SPILL

body: IT is no secret that New York City's growth has stopped. Indeed, the city's population declined during the 1970's. But what has received less attention in the months since the Census Bureau released its latest count are significant population shifts within the city. A computer analysis of the census poll by The New York Times found what may be the
title: THE REGION IN SUMMARY; POPULATION DECLINE HID BIG CHANGES

body: New York City's population shifted as dramatically during the decade of the 1970's as at any time in the history of the city. That is the conclusion of demographers, planners and other city experts who have now had several months to study the first reports from the 1980 census. Markedly Fewer Children The figures provide a profile of a shrinking
title: CENSUS TRACES RADICAL SHIFTS IN NEW YORK CITY'S POPULATION

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 15 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named eight that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and four that were closed for failure to do so. body: ''It took seven years of planning and pushing to turn this dump into a field,'' Carmine Santa Maria said yesterday. ''We consider it a miracle.'' The ''miracle'' is the Narrows Verrazano Youth Program Sports Complex in Brooklyn - 34 acres of park and playground that once was a landfill. At dedication ceremonies, Mr. Santa Maria, a member of the
title: LANDFILL IN BROOKLYN BECOMES SPORTS COMPLEX

body: The Feast of San Gennaro, granddaddy of New York street fairs, will swirl on all weekend under arches of colored lights on Mulberry Street, where the air is rich with the aroma of frying sausages and the blare of brass bands. Elsewhere this weekend, offspring of San Gennaro can be found on Manhattan's East Side and West Side and in TriBeCa, in
title: SAN GENNARO LEADS A PARADE OF FESTIVALS

body: The cooking schools listed on these pages were reviewed by Moira Hodgson and Bryan Miller. Judgments are based on the personality of the teacher and his or her knowledge of the subject, and the quality of the ingredients, kitchen and equipment used. Most of the classes were visited within the last two years. Alliance Fran,caise, 22 East 60th
title: THE GUIDE TO NEW YORK COOKING SCHOOLS: WHERE TO LOOK TO LEARN NEW CUISINES

body: Were the Dodgers returning to Brooklyn? Not likely. But State Senator Thomas J. Bartosiewicz of Brooklyn said he would like ''to bring major league baseball back to the borough that proved you can win by losing,'' and in February he got the State Legislature to approve $30,000 for a feasibility study of building a domed sports stadium for the
title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS; Brooklyn Stadium

body: A Brooklyn man shot at a group of 12 off-duty transit police officers in civilian clothes in Coney Island early yesterday after he and a friend made ''remarks with an ethnic overtone'' to them, the transit police said. None of the officers - 11 men and a woman -was hurt. Four of the officers returned the fire, slightly wounding the man, who was
title: 12 OFF-DUTY OFFICERS SHOT AT; WOUNDED BROOKLYN MAN HELD

body: Brighton Beach, long overshadowed by its more rambunctious neighbor, Coney Island, is having a street fair Sunday to show its stuff. There will be food, carnival rides, music, antiques, clothing and Brighton's great natural resource, the beach. The event, known as the Brighton Jubilee, will take place from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. along a six-block
title: AT BRIGHTON BEACH, A STREET FAIR HAS THE TANG OF THE SEA

body: The New York Times/John Sotomayor WALRUS PUPS FIND NEW HOME IN BROOKLYN: Nuka, right, and Denali, abandoned baby walruses that were found in Prudhoe Bay off Alaska, at their new home yesterday in the New York Aquarium in Coney Island. The 10-week-old pups, weighing 100 pounds each, were clinging to sandbags near an offshore drilling rig.
title: No Headline

body: A Day for the Rescuers W ith three beach weekends left in the official summer and a tally of some 2,000 swimmers plucked from trouble, most of the city's 458 beach and 400 pool lifeguards are about to go back to school as students or teachers. Yesterday, a great day at the shore, 120 local winners among the beach guards - 10 of them women -
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: An automobile struck a man in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, last night, severing his left leg at the knee. A police helicopter flew the victim and his leg, packed in ice, to Bellevue Hospital where a team of surgeons were working early this morning to reattach it. The driver of the car that hit the victim, Eugene Woyotkoski, 33 years old of the Borough
title: Car Severs Man's Leg; Team Works to Save It

body: An 85-year-old woman - her hands and feet bound with telephone cordwas found murdered late last night in her Upper West Side apartment a block from Columbia University, the police said. The police also reported the arrest of three men last night in two unrelated murders of elderly New Yorkers earlier this year. The woman who was murdered last night
title: WOMAN, 85, SLAIN NEAR COLUMBIA; 3 SEIZED IN EARLIER KILLINGS OF AGED

body: Detectives looking into the recent murders of five women found strangled in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn believe that no one killer was responsible in all cases, according to investigators. The investigators indicated that detectives made sufficient progress in the last week, in at least one case, to support that conclusion. However, police
title: POLICE DOUBTFUL OF SINGLE KILLER IN 5 STRANGLINGS

body: Taste is largely a matter of habit, and for almost four generations of Brooklynites, preferences for cakes, pies and pastries were to a large extent shaped by the buttery miracles turned out by the Ebinger Baking Company. By the time that family-run chain went bankrupt in 1972, there were 67 bright and gleaming Ebinger's bakeshops in Brooklyn,
title: DE GUSTIBUS; A BROOKLYN BAKERY ADDS NEW LUSTER TO EBINGER'S NAME

body: New York City inspectors yesterday began issuing orders to shut down 25 businesses with video games. The city says the presence of the games is illegal. A preliminary order issued in State Supreme Court in Manhattan last week by Acting Justice Thomas B. Galligan prohibits the arcade owners from using their premises for any purpose until they comply
title: THE CITY; 25 Video Arcades Get Order to Close

body: Dozens of detectives and other investigators are working virtually round the clock to analyze physical evidence and to trace the movements of five women killed in an unusual series of strangulations in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn. While some detectives sought to identify the latest victim, whose unclothed body was found Tuesday in the Narrows off
title: POLICE CONDUCT INTENSE SEARCH IN 5 STRANGLINGS

body: Dozens of New York City detectives intensified their efforts yesterday to solve the recent murder by strangulation of five women in Brooklyn and Manhattan. The latest victim, still unidentified yesterday, was found Tuesday in New York Bay off the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. Four of the murders have occurred in the last three weeks. The first was
title: FIVE STRANGLINGS OF CITY WOMEN PUZZLING POLICE

body: GRAND REOPENING The Cafe Versailles opens for previews tonight at 151 East 50th Street, where the old Versailles, source of three-dot items for a generation of gossip columnists and a New York base for Edith Piaf, flourished almost a half-century ago. It is also where, until recently Ibis, the club with an Egyptian flair and Nilotic decor did
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: The nude body of a young woman who had been sexually assaulted, beaten and strangled was found floating off the 69th Street Pier in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday. An electrical cord was tied around her neck and lashed around her hands behind her. It was the fourth known murder by strangulation of a woman in the city in less than three
title: WOMAN, KILLED BY STRANGLING, FOUND OFF PIER

body: THE AQUARIUM If it were set any other place in the country, it would be the major attraction of the area and people would drive hundreds of miles to visit it. But in this city the New York Aquarium, near the boardwalk in Coney Island, on Surf Avenue at West Eighth Street (266-8500), seems far away and is likely to be overlooked. It is a pity,
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: A Cleaner Coney Island C oney Island trumpeted its fourth million-plus crowd of the month yesterday, and some of those visiting the beaches thought that the year had brought improvement to the sand and the water. Sam Gonzalez, a shirt salesman from Brooklyn, was there with Irene Garcia, who works for a printing business. ''I kept away for a couple
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: 3-D Films on TV Bring Run on Stock of Glasses Remember 3-D, that relic of the 50's and once a big fad in New York? About 1.5 million pairs of 3-D eyeglasses have now been sold in New York in anticipation of two three-dimensional films on television. ''Gorilla at Large'' with Lee Marvin and Anne Bancroft will be shown today on WNET-TV at 3 P.M.
title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS

body: Two programs to fight arson,credited with success in other parts of New York City but with eld from the Bronx because of rivalry between the Fire and Police Departments, will both be operating in the borough starting today. The Fire Department's Red Cap project, so called because its 50 fire marshals wear red caps to make their presence known, will
title: BRONX IS GETTING 2 NEW PROGRAMS TO FIGHT ARSON

body: Lax supervision and poor work habits in its two major repair shops contribute to the breakdown and delay of many subway trains and cost the Transit Authority millions of dollars a year, according to a study released yesterday. The study, by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, found that maintenance and repair workers at a shop on207th Street in
title: REGAN CITES DELAY IN SUBWAY REPAIRS

body: Burglars with sledgehammers, acetylene torches and sophisticated electronic equipment bypassed an alarm system and broke into a Brooklyn bank early yesterday, but were thwarted by a vault-door alarm and two police officers who spotted two lookouts hiding in the bushes outside. Five suspects were arrested. The bungled burglary occurred at about 5
title: THE CITY; FIVE ARE ARRESTED IN BANK BURGLARY

body: Accessible by subway or bus, 15 miles of city beaches line the shores of four of the boroughs - all except Manhattan. The beaches, maintained by the city, are free, clean and, now that the freeze on hiring municipal employees has been lifted, fully staffed with lifeguards. ''The beaches can be reached by public transportation - that is their
title: NEW YORK CITY BEACHES: FREE AND EASY TO REACH

body: Three men posing as armored-car guards held up the Miller Bakery at 176 Woodward Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens, yesterday afternoon and took $17,000 at gunpoint. One of the men, identified as Keith Terry, 21 years old, of 300 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, ran into a nearby building, where he grappled with a retired police officer, Paul Teknus, 51. Mr.
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: On a day as bright as a diamond, New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors flocked to beaches and parks, an armada paraded on the Hudson and shrieking squadrons of jet fighters put on a spectacular show yesterday, as the long Fourth of July weekend drew to a close. It was a day of near perfection, with a brilliant sun glinting on emerald city
title: HOLIDAY CROWDS SAMPLE PRISTINE DAY'S PLEASURES

body: A group of business executives who spent a year studying the New York City subway system from within report that they have found archaic procedures, inefficient use of manpower, confused lines of authority and woeful customer relations. The executives paint a picture of a public agency with a $2 billion budget Excerpts from report, page B4. whose
title: A BUSINESS STUDY FINDS THE SUBWAYS TO BE BADLY RUN

body: Two Brooklyn residents climbed the parachute tower in the Coney Island Amusement Park yesterday and flew the flag of Puerto Rico from its top. Both were brought down by police officers, but it took them almost two hours to do so, the police reported. A police spokesman, Sgt. Leroy Barr, said Felix Santiago, 17 years old, of 1605 Mermaid Avenue, and
title: The City; 2 Climb Tower At Coney Island

body: Meira Rosenberg, an associate counsel with the legal-services plan of the Committee of Interns and Residents in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Stuart Bookman, a staff lawyer with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs. Rabbi Leon Waldman of Temple Beth-El in Fairfield, Conn., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's
title: Meira Rosenberg Wed To Robert Bookman

body: Charles Atlas, born Angelo Siciliano of Brooklyn, the Horatio Alger of the human body, has been dead for a decade now. Charles P. Roman keeps alive his legend. It has always been so. Was not Mr. Roman the man who, after Mr. Atlas had broken a metal bar in front of 3,000 inmates, called the tabloids and dictated the headline ''Man Breaks Bar at Sing
title: ABOUT NEW YORK

body: Two more young men were taken into police custody yesterday in last week's mob attack on three transit workers in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. The arrests brought to five the number of suspects in custody. One of the workers, William Turks, was beaten to death. Police officials have said the attack on the three workers, all of whom were
title: 2 MORE SUSPECTS SEIZED BY POLICE IN MOB ASSAULT

body: * Lee Mazzilli, the Brooklyn-born outfielder who played five seasons with the Mets before being traded to the Texas Rangers last spring, has missed five weeks of play with torn ligaments in his wrist. He is expected to return to active duty this week. He was batting .260 with two home runs and 12 runs batted in at the time of his injury. ''It's
title: Updates:; SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS

body: It was just after midnight on May 3 of last year. Roscoe Fountain had finished his 4 P.M.-to-midnight tour as a Housing Authority policeman at the Coney Island projects in Brooklyn. Officer Fountain was hungry. So he put on his civilian clothes and drove a few blocks, to the Gravesend section, to pick up something to eat before heading home. As he
title: A PLAYGROUND MOB, A KILLING AND A NEIGHBORHOOD ASKS WHY

body: Three men were attacked and one of them was beaten to death when their car stalled on a street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning. The victims, who were on their way home from work, were black, and the police said the attack was unprovoked and ''racially motivated.'' They said the victims were assaulted at 12:10 A.M. by a
title: BLACK MAN IS KILLED BY MOB IN BROOKLYN: ATTACK CALLED RACIAL

body: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the list of public beaches approved for swimming for the 1982 summer season. Following is a listing of the approved beaches: Brooklyn: Coney Island from Manhattan Beach to West 37th Street. Bronx: Orchard Beach, all of City Island and the Long Island Sound area from Lucerne Street to Schley
title: CITY LISTS APPROVED BEACHES

body: ANYONE who doubts that the man at the top can establish the tone and personality of a giant corporation might well consider the Waldbaum supermarket chain. Having only limited confidence in such modern business instruments as formal market research, Ira Waldbaum, the 54-year-old president of the chain, is a consummate pragmatist. He and his
title: A SUPERMARKET BOSS WITH A MOM-AND-POP PHILOSOPHY

body: The number of heroin addicts in New York City has increased by 50 percent since 1978, a new report to Governor Carey said yesterday. The report estimated that there were 163,000 to 177,500 addicts in the city, or one addict for every 40 to 43 residents. It said the total in New York State was 234,000, or one of every 75 residents. The report said
title: CALIFANO CITES 50% INCREASE IN HEROIN ADDICTION IN CITY

body: Seminar Center With Rabbits, Riv Vu It was news to Brooklyn Botanic Garden officials when they read in his recent autobiography, ''Yes to Life,'' that Corliss Lamont had arranged for the Garden to inherit his 30-acre estate in Ossining. It includes, he said fondly, ''woodlands, trails, a pond and a brook, rabbits, squirrels, occasional deer and a
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Part of each of New York City's seven beaches will be closed this weekend because the city cannot afford to hire 200 lifeguards and maintenance workers, Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis said yesterday. The beach closings - up to half of each beach will be affected - are the first visible effect of the hiring freeze ordered by Mayor Koch on
title: KOCH'S HIRING BAN HAS INITIAL EFFECT

body: IN addition to the Great Irish Fair in Brooklyn, streets and parks all over town will be alive this weekend with music, dance and other amusements. The largest of the fairs is the fifth annual Queens Day, a celebration that begins Sunday at 9:30 A.M. at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park and concludes hours later with a concert by the Queens Symphony
title: QUEENS DAY LEADS A WEEKEND FULL OF FAIRS

body: The New York City Department of Health released the names of seven restaurants last week that were cited for violations of the city's health code. The department also named seven that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and four that were closed for failure to do so. The establishments were listed as follows: VIOLATIONS Moon
title: 7 Food Establishments Cited For Violations of Health Code

body: NO matter that the solstice is three weeks away; summer as a way of life starts today. The Memorial Day weekend ushers in the season just as Labor Day snuffs it out, and there are all kinds of ways to get into the spirit over the next four days in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. There are lazy ways, like lying on the beaches - which open
title: MEMORIAL DAY: A 3-STATE GUIDE TO THE START OF SUMMER

body: Millions of feet trample them and thousands of wheels ride over them each day, yet they never gain attention until they blow sky-high in a freak accident. Yet they have caught the eye of an artistphotographer, Hertha Bauer, whose ''Mostly Manhole Covers of Manhattan'' displays about 100 of them in the Community Gallery, at 30 East 35th Street
title: GOING OUT GUIDE; COVERS UP

body: As New Yorkers take to the roads for their first long weekend of the season, they are likely to encounter fewer traffic bottlenecks than on Memorial Days past. ''Construction delays for those headed for the shore should pose less of a problem this year,'' said John A. Marino Jr., head of the New York City office of the state's Transportation
title: TRAFFIC OUTLOOK: SMOOTH SUMMER, BUT TROUBLE DOWN THE ROAD

body: One man was stabbed and several young people were injured yesterday during a melee near a Brooklyn subway station shortly after 400 students were allowed to leave a high school early because of racial tensions, the police said. There was one arrest. Ira Ewen, the principal of James Madison High School, where the students were from, would not
title: FIGHTING ERUPTS AS STUDENTS GET EARLY DISMISSAL

body: It isn't 1947 here, but it might as well be. Extras stroll through Rockaway's Playland in vintage summer clothes, the women wearing impeccable 40's makeup and hairdos. ''Hey, sailor, I got a dame for you,'' jokes one gray-haired extra to another, who's in uniform. Little girls in ringlets play catch for the camera, then slip anachronistically into
title: BRINGING 'SOPHIE'S CHOICE' TO THE SCREEN

body: On a cool spring evening last week that belied the coming of hot summer nights in New York, children played basketball on the asphalt courts near the Brevoort Housing Project in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. But some children had passed up the game to sit in the project's basement with their mothers, and for them the choice had been
title: FRESH AIR FUND CAMPS DRAW EAGER YOUNGSTERS

body: AGENERAL contractor named Thomas Delmazio has his office on the c orner of 71st Street and 20th Avenue in the Bensonhurst section of B rooklyn. He has done apartment-renovation work in northern Flatbush a nd Coney Island, but not in Bensonhurst. That disappoints him as much as it surprises the visitor to Bensonhurst. Fully occupied apartments
title: REHABILITATION LAGS IN THE BETTER AREAS

body: 1633. STORY TIME, informal readings, Saturday and Sunday at 3 and 4 P.M., Children's Bookshop, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street. Pay-what-you-wish. Information: 879-5500. Sail Around Manhatan CIRCLE LINE SIGHTSEEING YACHTS, three-hour cruise around Manhattan, passes historic sights, landmarks and bridges. Vessels leave from
title: For Children; Music and Stories

body: EGGS will fly at the Bronx Zoo. People will careen in Brooklyn. Eeyore will munch poundcake. Pedestrians will amble. Radio City will simulate dawn. These are a few of the events that will take place this Easter weekend as spring tries to settle in irrevocably. The zoo phenomenon will be the annual ''Great Egg Event,'' a sixday celebration beginning
title: FAMILY FARE FOR EASTER IN CITY AND SUBURB

body: A medley of spring weather - blustering winds, falling temperatures, choruses of somber gray skies and occasional snow flurries - swept over the New York area yesterday, discouraging outdoor play but causing few power or transportation problems. It was a modest reprise of the lightning-wracked thunderstorms and 60-mile-an-hour gusts that assailed
title: HIGH WIND RULES DAY IN THE CITY

body: A supermarket in the South Bronx paid a $4,365 electricity bill last month. It might have paid $5,573, had it not been for a rate reduction of almost 22 percent from Consolidated Edison. A small doll factory in Brooklyn paid $174 instead of the $218 it would normally have been billed, and a Bronx plastics manufacturer whose February electricity
title: CON ED'S DISCOUNTS HELP GENERATE NEW JOBS

body: Additions have been made to the Children's Zoo at the Bronx Zoo, but you won't find them without help. They are camouflaged nests for squirrels, robins, blue jays and cardinals, all hidden in trees. Telescopes are provided so youngsters can spot them. The three-acre children's facility -which opens for the season today -encourages youngsters to act
title: WEEKENDER GUIDE; Friday; HIDING OUT AT BRONX ZOO

body: The New York City Department of Health cited eight food establishments last week for violations of the city's Health Code. It also listed seven that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and 12 that were closed for failure to do so. VIOLATIONS Bagel And, 51 Christopher St. David Copperfield, 322 Lexington Ave. Foo Chow, 1278
title: 8 Food Places Charged With Health Violations

body: By Mary Cantwell MAE WEST: A Biography by George Eells and Stanley Musgrove. Morrow. 351 pages $15.50 FEDERICO FELLINI wanted to cast Mae West as an ''erotic'' witch in his ''Satyricon.'' She was tempted until she found out that the witch was a mother. Just as well: Mae West as mother is a grotesquery that even the most ardent Fellini fan could not
title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times

body: Reasoning that there is strength in numbers, the New York City Transit Authority recently began setting aside special areas on subway platforms where passengers could congregate late at night while waiting for trains. As conceived by transit officials, the ''off-hours waiting area'' would be a low-budget item that would require little more than
title: FOR OFF-HOURS, SUBWAY ZONES FOR SAFER WAIT

body: THE setting was a modern loft in Lower Manhattan, the music was traditional Bulgarian, and the atmosphere was electric. More than 100 dancers, ranging in age from the late 20's to the early 60's, each grasping a neighbor by the belt, swirled around the spacious dance floor of the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, stamping out a dance called the kopcheto. As
title: WHERE TO TEXAS TWO-STEP OR CZARDAS ANY NIGHT

body: A gasoline tanker exploded, burst into flames and sank in the East River yesterday morning, killing one crew member and injuring three others, moments after it passed under the Williamsburg Bridge. A huge chunk of steel was flung 135 feet into the air and landed on the subway tracks of the bridge, halting one train and closing the bridge to cars
title: SEAMAN IS KILLED AS TANKER SINKS INTO EAST RIVER

body: ''BROOKLYN don't seem to be like any other place on earth,'' opined George Washington Plunkitt, boss of Manhattan's 15th Assembly District, around the turn of the century. ''Once let a man grow up amidst Brooklyn's cobblestones, with the odor of Newtown Creek and Gowanus Canal ever in his nostrils, and there's no place in the world for him except
title: ART: VISITS OF BROOKLYN BEFORE THE BRIDGE

body: A 34-year-old man suspected of having committed about 50 robberies in physicians' and dentists' offices since October shot himself to death in his Brooklyn motel room early yesterday when he saw the police closing in. Detectives said that the suspect, Robert Scheff of Brooklyn, had held up professional offices in Brooklyn and Queens, robbing
title: HOLDUP SUSPECT IS A SUICIDE AS POLICE CLOSE IN

body: The Parks Department is using German shepherd dogs to guard some of its most frequently vandalized buildings and other parks facilities in Brooklyn, as part of a major reorganization of its security operations. By next year watchdogs or mobile two-officer teams or both are expected to replace night watchmen in more than 80 park sites throughout the
title: CITY DEPLOYING GUARD DOGS TO PATROL BUILDINGS IN PARKS

body: Two gunmen may have taken part in the slaying of an off-duty Housing Authority police officer shortly after midnight yesterday near his home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said. The officer, James Carragher, 54 years old, who had just completed a tour of duty in Coney Island, was slain 80 feet from his front door in the Glenwood
title: POLICE LOOKING FOR 2 IN BROOKLYN SLAYING OF A HOUSING OFFICER

body: Courtroom 525 in the State Supreme Court building in Brooklyn is decorated in light wood and dominated by the words ''All Persons Are Equal Before the Law,'' carved into the long back wall. Like most courtrooms, it resembles a church, with long pews for those in attendance and a raised platform for the judge and his acolytes. Those who move in and
title: ABOUT NEW YORK

body: PARKS are one of the few places where city dwellers can get a real sense of the seasonal changes that once directed human life. Most people seem to prefer to witness winter from behind a steamy apartment window. The parks seem deserted then, with only a few dog walkers and joggers to witness their bleak beauty and new serenity. But this Sunday,
title: SUNDAY WALK TO SCALE HEIGHTS OF PROSPECT PARK

body: Paul Theroux, whose latest novel, ''Mosquito Coast,'' will be published next month, lives in London. By Paul Theroux New Yorkers say some terrible things about the subway - that they hate it, or are scared stiff of it, or that it deserves to go broke. ''I haven't been down there in years,'' is a common enough remark from a city dweller. Even people
title: SUBWAY ODYSSEY

body: Representative Stephen J. Solarz was in Cleveland the other day delivering a fervent address on the security and survival of Israel. As he drew to a close, Mr. Solarz, who speaks in a manner that is both confident and affable, came to the matter closest to his heart and the real reason he had flown more than 1,000 miles for a two-hour visit. ''Like
title: SOLARZ PLANS FOR A RACE TO KEEP BROOKLYN SEAT

body: A new progr am aimed at getting more physicians to practice in municipal hos pital clinics was approved yesterday by the New York City Health a nd Hospitals Corporation. It would give them some of the same financial and professional incentives they would realize in private practice. The program is also aimed at improving the quality of medical care
title: CITY ACTS TO ATTRACT DOCTORS TO WORK IN HOSPITAL CLINICS

body: Sol David, who survived Nazi concentration camps in World War II only to be murdered in Brooklyn by a robber who killed him with a single bullet, was buried yesterday. With Mr. David's widow, Flora, sobbing uncontrollably as relatives sought to comfort her, Rabbi Paul Gruber told more than 50 mourners at the Flatbush funeral service that ''we
title: A DEATH CAMP SURVIVOR, SLAIN BY MUGGERS, BURIED

body: More than a third of the 42 hospitals in New York City seeking official designation to receive emergency ambulance patients have failed to meet qualifying standards. As a result, city officials said yesterday that they would modify or waive the standards rather than exclude any hospitals. To do otherwise, the officials said, would severely damage
title: CITY MAY EASE RULES HOSPITALS CAN'T FOLLOW

body: Fred Moran, whose family owned and operated the Thunderbolt roller coaster at Coney Island for more than 50 years, died Friday at Veterans Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 64 years old. Mr. Moran's home and small office were situated under the roller coaster's tracks and they trembled as the cars sped overhead. His father, the late George H. Moran, had
title: FRED MORAN, OWNER OF THUNDERBOLT RIDE AT CONEY ISLAND PARK

body: A man was shot to death and the operator of an all-night newspaper stand was critically wounded early yesterday at a deserted intersection in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, the police said. The news dealer, 55-year-old Thomas Cazzo, of 67 28th Avenue in Bensonhurst, was listed in critical condition last night at Coney Island Hospital with a
title: 2 SHOT, ONE FATALLY OUTSIDE A NEWSSTAND ON BROOKLYN CORNER

body: The innocent bystander who was killed in what was apparently a gangland attack on two men in Brooklyn Monday night was described yesterday as a social worker who had devoted her life to helping others. The bystander, Veronica Zuraw, 53 years old, was killed in her kitchen by a shotgun blast that penetrated the second-floor door and walls of he r
title: BYSTANDER KILLED IN MOB SHOOTING WAS A SOCIAL WORKER AND EX-NUN

body: Leftovers from other children's trays were fed yesterday to some of about 50 children in a Brooklyn elementary school who returned from winter vacation to find they were no longer e ligible for free hot lunches. Most of the se children had failed to return completed forms that are required under new Federal regulations to determine eligibility for
title: BROOKLYN PUPILS FED OTHERS' LUNCH LEFTOVERS

body: Two people - one of them a woman storing laundry in a hallway closet in her home - were killed during a gangland attempt to assassinate a convicted pornographer and Mafia member last night on a quiet, residential side street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, the police said. A third person was seriously wounded by men firing shotguns from at
title: TWO SLAIN AND ONE HURT IN A MOB-STYLE SHOOTING
